Ninetales-Alola.overview:
• Weather control in Snow Warning and Aurora Veil support give Alolan Ninetales a strong niche in the metagame. Alolan Ninetales's great offensive typing allows it to threaten Chien-Pao, Urshifu-S, and Landorus with an OHKO while also walling the former two.

  • Alolan Ninetales pairs especially well with slower Ice-types that appreciate the added bulk from snow, such as Articuno and Baxcalibur. Hisuian Arcanine also makes for an excellent partner, helping Alolan Ninetales set up Aurora Veil through Intimidate support, dishing out great damage, and threatening Ice-resistant foes, such as Gholdengo, Incineroar, and Kingambit. All of these partners have fantastic offensive pressure through setup or Choice items, making up for Alolan Ninetales's poor offenses. Ogerpon-W does a great job at helping set up Aurora Veil with Follow Me and threatening foes that resist Ice-type moves like Incineroar with Ivy Cudgel.

  • Alolan Ninetales struggles against opposing weather setters such as Tornadus, which can shut down the snow composition. Fire- and Steel-types such as Gholdengo and Chi-Yu are threats, as they resist Ninetales-Alola's and Articuno's Ice-type STAB moves, as well as ignoring Ogerpon-W's Follow Me through Make It Rain and Heat Wave.

Screen Setter.description:
• Moonblast guarantees a 2HKO on Urshifu-R. Helping Hand helps make up for Alolan Ninetales's poor damage output.

  • Light Clay is used to make sure Aurora Veil lasts for the majority of the game.

  • The defensive investment allows Alolan Ninetales to survive Choice Specs Flutter Mane's Moonblast and avoid the 2HKO from Ogerpon-W's Ivy Cudgel and Rillaboom's Wood Hammer, while the Speed investment allows it to outspeed Landorus.

  • Tera Fire allows Alolan Ninetales to resist the Fire- and Steel-type moves that otherwise give it trouble, such as Gholdengo's Make it Rain and Ogerpon-H's STAB moves.

Arcanine-Hisui.overview:
• Hisuian Arcanine is a potent offensive Pokemon on many teams thanks to its good Attack, great STAB coverage, and excellent ability in Intimidate, giving it good matchups against Tornadus, Rillaboom, and Chien-Pao.

  • Hisuian Arcanine works best in Tailwind compositions where its average Speed and poor defensive typing don't often hold it back, hence why Tailwind setters like Tornadus make good partners. In return, Hisuian Arcanine can provide Tornadus with Intimidate support, letting it stick around longer and support it with Tailwind or Bleakwind Storm damage.

  • Hisuian Arcanine can be severely overwhelmed by Pokemon like Urshifu-R and Landorus, making Pokemon like Rillaboom and Latias good partners. Hisuian Arcanine also can be hindered heavily from other Intimidate users like Incineroar, meaning it appreciate having Pokemon like Landorus which can threaten it.

Choice Band.description:
• Tera Blast with Tera Fairy can hit foes like Urshifu-R, Urshifu, and Raging Bolt, the former of which walls Hisuian Arcanine's STABs. Head Smash can be used to threaten Pokemon like Incineroar and Ogerpon-W with an OHKO at the cost of being chipped down by recoil.

  • Choice Band boosts Hisuian Arcanine's damage, allowing for OHKOs on top threats like Urshifu-R, Kingambit, and Ogerpon-H.

  • The given EV spread lets Hisuian Arcanine take two unboosted Flutter Mane Shadow Balls and almost always survive a Stomping Tantrum from Ogerpon-H. The Speed EVs let it outspeed Regieleki in Tailwind.

  • Tera Fairy lets Hisuian Arcanine remove its weakness to Fighting-type attacks, which can be useful in a pinch against Chien-Pao; this can also let it survive Surging Strikes from Mystic Water Urshifu-R. Tera Normal boosts Extreme Speed's damage, which can be helpful against neutral targets like Urshifu-R.

Electabuzz.comments:
Teambuilding

  • Electabuzz is good as a support piece on balance teams, redirecting attacks like Electro Shot and Flash Cannon from Archaludon. Electabuzz also can slow down foes along the lines of Pelipper, letting partners like Rillaboom and Primarina outspeed them.

  • Electabuzz, thanks to its access to Follow Me, works well as a partner for setup Pokemon such as Kingambit, Volcarona, and Kommo-o, allowing them to set up with ease. Dragapult and Sneasler also appreciate the support of Electabuzz, as it can shut down Trick Room while helping keep these frail Pokemon healthy with Follow Me.

  • Electabuzz can really struggle into Taunt, which shuts it down almost entirely. Ground-types like the Ursaluna formes can easily ignore Electabuzz, hitting it really hard with Earth Power and Headlong Rush while being immune to Electroweb. Allies like Rillaboom and Primarina can threaten Ursaluna, while Taunt can be denied with faster Taunt or Fake Out from allies such as Talonflame and Rillaboom, respectively.

Strategy Comments

  • Electabuzz's main role is being a redirection support Pokemon with an immunity to sleep from Sneasler and Amoonguss. Electabuzz is best used next to a powerful setup sweeper like Kingambit.

  • Electabuzz works best as a early-game redirector that can come back in the late-game to protect allies from some key attacks.

  • Even though Electabuzz is bulky, it can still easily get overwhelmed by constant damage or super effective attacks from foes like Dragapult and Ursaluna. Taunt prevents Electabuzz from supporting with Follow Me or using Protect, which makes it easier to get overwhelmed. Terastallization or allies that can eliminate these foes like Primarina can stop the overwhelming damage. Faster Taunt, Fake Out, or switching can stop opposing Taunt.

Support.description:
• Electabuzz works as a good bulky redirector that can redirect away sleep in Spore and Dire Claw while denying Trick Room with Taunt and slowing opposing Pokemon down, utilizing its good Speed.

  • Electroweb can do decent chip damage while providing speed control, slowing down threats such as Rillaboom and Dragonite. Taunt can deny redirection from Pokemon such as Amoonguss and Clefable, but more importantly, Taunt can shut down Trick Room from Pokemon such as Porygon2 and Indeedee-F.

  • Eviolite grants immense bulk to Electabuzz, allowing it to redirect more attacks and support for longer.

  • Tera Ghost provides an immunity to Fake Out, removing a potential hindrance to its support. Tera Ghost also shuts down Sneasler but makes Electabuzz weak to Kingambit and Basculegion. Tera Fairy leaves Electabuzz not weak to most of the metagame's attacks and helps into Kingambit that aren't using Iron Head, as well as the many Dragon-type Pokemon in the format like Dragapult and Dragonite, at the cost of being weak to Gholdengo and Sneasler.

  • The Defense investment lets Electabuzz take Guts-boosted Headlong Rush from Ursaluna after it Terastallizes while also surviving Stomping Tantrum from Life Orb Garchomp. The Special Defense investment lives a +2 Draco Meteor from Archaludon as well as easily taking a Choice Specs Shadow Ball from Gholdengo. The Speed outspeeds Timid Pelipper.

Magmar.comments:
Teambuilding

  • Since Magmarâ€™s primary role is redirection, it pairs best with teammates that can either apply immediate offensive pressure or set up for a potential sweep. Although there are other popular teammates like Gholdengo and Dragonite that work well with it, Magmar has been used mainly on a specific balance composition, consisting of Kingambit, Rillaboom, Sneasler, Primarina, and Dragapult to round out the Fire / Water / Grass core.
  • Kingambit is a great partner for Magmar because it can set up safely with Swords Dance and exert significant offensive pressure. Plus, with priority Sucker Punch, Magmar realistically only needs to buy Kingambit one turn. Similarly, Gholdengo is another great partner for it, safely stacking Nasty Plot boosts and sweeping with Make It Rain. Additionally, Magmar can redirect potential Sucker Punch from an opposing Kingambit and burn it with Will-O-Wisp so Gholdengo doesn't outright lose to Kingambit.
  • Rillaboom synergizes with Magmar by providing coverage for common Water-types like Primarina and Basculegion-M and Ground-types like Ursaluna-B that threaten Magmar. In return, Magmar redirects attacks that threaten Rillaboom, most importantly Dire Claw from Sneasler.
  • Primarina works well with Magmar, as it will safely chip away at foes with Hyper Voice without worrying about Dire Claw, Wood Hammer, or Spore from Sneasler, Rillaboom, and Amoonguss. Magmar also pressures Steel-types like Gholdengo and Assault Vest Kingambit that Primarina has a hard time against.
  • Sneasler puts pressure on many relevant Pokemon, including those that Magmar struggles against, like Archaludon and Primarina. Magmar supports Sneasler by helping it maintain its Focus Sash for longer and focus on its role as a glass cannon. Also acting as a glass cannon, Dragapult appreciates redirection, which allows it to safely spam Dragon Darts and deal large amounts of chip damage to both foes.

Strategy Comments

  • Magmar's playstyle is straightforward; it enables its teammates to secure KOs while it tanks the hits. For balance compositions, it's the defensive backbone of the team.
  • Typically, Magmar is better as a lead to safely establish early-game offensive dominance with glass cannons like Sneasler and Dragapult or setup sweepers like Swords Dance Kingambit. Once Magmar has fainted and momentum has been established, you can bring in another offensive threat and clean up.
  • One of the biggest flaws of Magmar is spread damage. While this largely can't be avoided, some of the common spread moves can be mitigated with the proper positioning. For example, Expanding Force in Psychic Terrain can be made single target by a well-timed Rillaboom swap, and Eruption from Hisuian Typhlosion can be tanked well by Primarina, which can dish back solid damage. Magmar also struggles against standard Archaludon rain teams. To deal with this, Sneasler, Rillaboom, and Kingambit are solid choices. Sneasler threatens Archaludon with its STAB attacks even if Archaludon Terastallizes, while Rillaboom can handle Basculegion-M effectively. Kingambit pressures everything with boosted Sucker Punch, especially Archaludon before it accumulates too many Stamina boosts.

Bulky Redirector.description:
• Magmarâ€™s role is to redirect attacks with Follow Me, allowing its teammates to set up or attack safely.
  • Vital Spirit lets Magmar redirect status moves like Spore and Sleep Powder from Pokemon such as Amoonguss and Vivillon without being put to sleep. Flame Body can punish certain physical attackers like Rillaboom, Sneasler, and Kingambit by redirecting their attacks and potentially burning them.
  • Overheat is used for a large burst of damage, while Heat Wave is sometimes preferred for its consistency, providing spread chip damage without the Special Attack drop. Will-O-Wisp is useful for pressuring physical attackers like Sneasler and Dragonite as well as physical setup threats like Kingambit. Clear Smog can be useful for hindering certain setup Pokemon like Quiver Dance Volcarona.
  • Tera Ghost, especially when Magmar's teammate can't use Protect, is particularly helpful for gaining a Fake Out immunity to allow it to click Follow Me.
  • The Defense investment lets Magmar comfortably take a Stomping Tantrum from Life Orb Garchomp, withstand two hits from Tera Dragon Dragon Darts from Choice Band Dragapult, and nearly always survive Population Bomb from Maushold. The Special Defense investment allows it to take Weather Ball from Timid Pelipper.

Articuno.overview:
• Articuno has a unique niche in the metagame thanks strong Ice-type STAB attacks and great bulk. Blizzard allows Articuno to tear through common cores utilizing Rillaboom, Landorus, and Raging Bolt.

  • Alolan Ninetales is mandatory with Articuno, patching up Blizzard's accuracy and amplifying its bulk and damage output through snow, Aurora Veil, and Helping Hand. Landorus makes for a great offensive partner, threatening Ice-resistant foes like Incineroar, Gholdengo, and Kingambit. Articuno is capable of removing Ground-immune foes like Dragonite and opposing Landorus in return.

  • Articuno's lack of coverage means aforementioned Ice resists such as Incineroar, Gholdengo, and Kingambit are problematic. Opposing weather from setters like Sunny Day and Rain Dance Tornadus are also an issue, as Articuno becomes a lot easier to remove without the added bulk and accurate Blizzards.

Choice Specs.description:
• Blizzard is used as Articuno's primary Ice-type STAB move, as it threatens both opponents. Ice Beam is used for a strong single-target attack, and Freeze-Dry is chosen to threaten Water-types like Ogerpon-W, Urshifu-R, and Terastallized Amoonguss, which otherwise take it's hits exceptionally well. Sheer Cold is preferred in the last moveslot to threaten bulky Ice-resistant foes such as Incineroar, Dondozo, and Kingambit.

  • Choice Specs allows Articuno to 2HKO Flutter Mane and Terastallized Ogerpon-W with Ice Beam and Freeze-Dry, respectively.

  • The given EV spread lets Articuno almost always avoid the 2HKO from Choice Specs Flutter Mane's Tera Fairy Dazzling Gleam and almost always survive Ogerpon-H's Tera Fire Ivy Cudgel under snow and Aurora Veil.

  • Articuno utilizes Tera Ice to shed its weakness to Raging Bolt's Thunderclap and keep the Defense boost from snow as well as make up for its mediocre damage output. This is because snow and Aurora Veil allow Articuno to function in seemingly bad matchups without a defensive Tera type.

Dragonite.overview:
• Dragonite's great movepool, well-rounded stats, great ability in Inner Focus that makes it immune to Fake Out and Intimidate from Incineroar, and stellar matchups into threats like Urshifu-R, Rillaboom, and Ogerpon-W makes Dragonite a great Pokemon in Regulation F.

  • When holding a Choice Band, Dragonite becomes one of the scariest Pokemon in the metagame for its breaking power. Its best partner, Chien-Pao, supports it with Sword of Ruin and pressures Pokemon that prevent Extreme Speed, such as Indeedee and Flutter Mane. Dragonite and Chien-Pao also are good into Rillaboom and Ogerpon-W, making Dondozo and Tatsugiri, which struggle with these two, great partners as well.

  • Flutter Mane is also a great partner, as it breaks through Iron Hands and Gholdengo for Dragonite, while Dragonite is a great switch into Scarf Urshifu-R and Rillaboom.

Choice Band.description:
• Extreme Speed is a priority move that hits the majority of the metagame for neutral damage, making it ideal to lock into.

  • Aerial Ace allows Dragonite to OHKO Pokemon like Urshifu-R, Rillaboom, and Amoongus without having to be lock into Outrage. Aqua Jet is secondary priority and allows it to double up with its partner on Ghost-types like Flutter Mane, and Ice Spinner allows it to remove Indeedee-F's Psychic Terrain while still having coverage for Pokemon like Rillaboom and Amoongus.

  • Outrage is used as its Dragon-type STAB move and allows it to OHKO almost the entire metagame.

  • Stomping Tantrum gives coverage into Steel-types like Kingambit and Archaludon.

  • The Speed EVs allow Dragonite to outspeed Dragapult in Tailwind, with the remaining EVs maximize its Attack and round out its bulk, allowing it to live attacks such as Choice Specs Flutter Mane's Dazzling Gleam

  • Normal is used as the Tera type, boosting Dragonite's Extreme Speed to stellar levels of power and removing its weaknesses to common Fairy- and Ice-type moves.

Typhlosion-Hisui.comments:
Teambuilding

  • Hisuian Typhlosion works best with Pokemon that help it attack before taking damage, which could weaken Eruption. Whimsicott and Galarian Weezing are two examples of this, with Whimsicott setting priority Tailwind and Galarian Weezing shutting down opposing Prankster Pokemon, something that pairs even better with Choice Scarf Hisuian Typhlosion, as it can outspeed and OHKO opposing Whimsicott. Redirection from Indeedee-F and Electabuzz helps Hisuian Typhlosion attack without having the Base Power of Eruption lowered, though it doesn't help against spread moves. Choice Specs is almost always paired with Prankster Tailwind support, mainly from Whimsicott, that allows Hisuian Typhlosion to outspeed the entire unboosted metagame. On the other hand, Choice Scarf is used on a variety of teams, as the Speed boost makes it less reliant on speed control.
  • The aforementioned Whimsicott and Galarian Weezing are good partners, but they don't have much of an offensive presence. More offensive Pokemon like Garchomp and Ursaluna-B can help mitigate this, threatening Kingambit and appreciating Hisuian Typhlosion's good matchup into Rillaboom.
  • Priority attacks like Kingambit's Sucker Punch can be a problem for Hisuian Typhlosion, as they weaken Eruption as well as threatening it for super effective damage. Indeedee-M can block priority attacks with Psychic Surge and threaten Incineroar, Kingambit, and Tyranitar, which Hisuian Typhlosion struggles with, with Tera Blast Fighting.

Strategy Comments

  • Hisuian Typhlosion is purely an offensive Pokemon, functioning best when one or both foes can be KOed by Eruption.
  • Hisuian Typhlosion works best as a lead, though it can also work as a late-game cleaner in matchups where the opponent has led with counters for it in previous games.
  • Hisuian Typhlosion struggles the most with specially defensive Pokemon like Assault Vest Kingambit and Pokemon that resist its Fire-type STAB moves like Incineroar. This can be mitigated by bringing Hisuian Typhlosion in the back or by using it to chip these Pokemon and clear the way for a partner late-game.

Glass Cannon.description:
• Hisuian Typhlosion has one job: spam powerful Fire-type moves.
  • Eruption is the main STAB attack of choice for Hisuian Typhlosion due to its high Base Power and spread damage, while Heat Wave can be used if Hisuian Typhlosion's health is lowered or at risk of being lowered by a foe's attack. Overheat gives Hisuian Typhlosion an option for single-target burst damage, letting it OHKO Porygon2 when paired with Tera Fire and Sunny Day support at the cost of being less spammable and often forcing a switch out. Overheat also bypasses Wide Guard, meaning that Hisuian Typhlosion can attack without having to play mindgames.
  • Choice Specs increases Hisuian Typhlosion's damage output, allowing it to OHKO Assault Vest Kingambit sets, while Choice Scarf lets it outspeed Dragapult and Sneasler.
  • Tera Fire maximizes the damage from Eruption, letting Choice Scarf sets OHKO Assault Vest Rillaboom and Choice Specs sets OHKO Archaludon and Porygon2 in sun.

Porygon2.comments:
Teambuilding

  • Thanks to its offensive and defensive tools, Porygon2 fits well on balance teams with a Trick Room mode. It benefits from teammates that provide utility, such as Fake Out or redirection, enabling it to set up Trick Room and go on the offensive, as well as teammates that can take advantage of Trick Room.
  • Porygon2 is most commonly paired with Incineroar, which offers Fake Out support to allow Porygon2 to set up Trick Room. It also provides Intimidate and Parting Shot utility, enhancing Porygon2â€™s survivability. Parting Shot is especially valuable, as it allows Incineroar to pivot to a Trick Room sweeper while Porygon2 sets up Trick Room. Additionally, Incineroarâ€™s access to Flare Blitz and Knock Off helps to threaten Pokemon like Gholdengo, which would otherwise wall Porygon2.
  • The preferred Trick Room sweeper for Porygon2 teams is Ursaluna, as it takes full advantage of Trick Room by securing OHKOs on many Pokemon with its Guts boost. This pairing also works well because Porygon2 threatens special damage, while Ursaluna dishes out massive physical damage. Garchomp is another excellent offensive partner for Porygon2 because Garchomp provides a faster-paced, non-Trick Room-dependent offensive option for Porygon2 but with a less explosive damage output than Ursaluna.
  • Amoonguss is a common support partner for Porygon2, taking full advantage of Trick Room with its low Speed and putting foes to sleep with Spore to allow Porygon2 to attack unthreatened. It also provides Rage Powder redirection, enabling Porygon2 to set up Trick Room freely, and Pollen Puff to heal Porygon2, reducing the need for it to constantly use Recover.
  • Gholdengo is a common offensive partner for Porygon2, as it walls Pokemon like non-Throat Chop Sneasler, which can threaten massive damage to Porygon2, and Amoonguss, which can disrupt Porygon2 by putting it to sleep with Spore before it sets up Trick Room or deals much damage. Additionally, the threat of Nasty Plot boosts forces opponents to focus on Gholdengo, potentially allowing Porygon2 to move freely.
  • Flamigo and Sneasler are used on Porygon2 teams, as they threaten Incineroar, which can hinder Porygon2 with Knock Off and Parting Shot, as well as threats like Archaludon, Kingambit, and, in Flamigo's case, Gholdengo with Close Combat. Sneasler has the added benefit of threatening status with Dire Claw and Poison Touch, while Flamigo has Wide Guard utility to protect Porygon2 from moves like Eruption from Hisuian Typhlosion and Make It Rain from Gholdengo.

Strategy Comments

  • As a defensive unit with offensive potential, Porygon2 excels when it is minimally threatened by high-damage moves, such as Close Combat from Sneasler and Choice Specs Tera Fire Eruption from Hisuian Typhlosion. This necessitates pivoting and relying on its teammates to handle major damage dealers, enabling Porygon2 to safely set up Trick Room, heal itself as needed, and retaliate with substantial damage.
  • The optimal strategy for using Porygon2 involves pivoting between Pokemon like Incineroar and Amoonguss until Porygon2 and its partner sweepers like Ursaluna achieve a strong offensive position. This includes cycling Intimidate and Parting Shot with Incineroar to stack stat drops while using Amoonguss's Spore to stop opposing threats. By doing so, you create a window for Porygon2 and its offensive partners to safely attack and capitalize on the advantageous board state.
  • Due to Porygon2's relatively unoppressive presence, it's susceptible to being outpaced offensively, which is largely unavoidable. However, the best way to deal with this is by pivoting between teammates like Incineroar and Amoonguss to cycle Intimidate, use Spore, or provide redirection until Porygon2 and its offensive partner are in a favorable position. As mentioned earlier, Incineroar's Knock Off and Parting Shot significantly impair Porygon2's offensive and defensive capabilities, which is why Pokemon like Garchomp and Flamigo are employed to take down Incineroar. Additionally, cycling Fake Out from Incineroar and Rillaboom can be particularly threatening for Porygon2, as it may allow an opposing Pokemon to set up or chip away at Porygon2, potentially causing it to faint before it can use Recover. This is why Pokemon like Flamigo and Sneasler are often included, as they can threaten common Fake Out users as well as setup threats like Kingambit and Gholdengo.

Offensive Trick Room Setter.description:
• Porygon2â€™s primary role is to absorb hits, set up Trick Room, and exert offensive pressure while Trick Room is active. With Eviolite, Porygon2 becomes one of the bulkiest Pokemon in the format, and its access to Recover allows it to heal and remain difficult to remove. Additionally, the Download boost helps it gain more offensive pressure.
  • Tera Blast is essential to Porygon2's set, as it provides the necessary coverage to make Porygon2 offensively threatening once it's Terastallized. Ice Beam is also crucial, offering good coverage against Pokemon like Garchomp and Dragonite.
  • Tera Fighting is used for Fighting-type Tera Blast, enabling Porygon2 to deal significant damage to Steel- and Dark-type Pokemon such as Kingambit, Archaludon, and Incineroar. Tera Blast Ground also targets Steel-types but has the niche of threatening Pokemon like Electabuzz, Magmar, and Gholdengo. Tera Flying serves a slightly different purpose; while Flying-type Tera Blast is effective against threats like Rillaboom and Annihilape, it is primarily used for its resistance to Fighting-type moves and immunity to Ground-type attacks. This allows Porygon2's common partner, Ursaluna, to freely use Earthquake without worrying about hitting Porygon2.
  • With the provided Defense and HP investment, Porygon2 can almost always survive two Kowtow Cleaves from Black Glasses Tera Dark Kingambit, a Wave Crash from Tera Water Choice Band Basculegion-M in rain, and two Wood Hammers from most Assault Vest Rillaboom. The Special Defense investment allows it to live three Hyper Voices from Life Orb Primarina as well as a Make It Rain from Leftovers Gholdengo after two Nasty Plot boosts. The Special Attack investment ensures that Porygon2 can KO Garchomp with Ice Beam or with a Download-boosted Tera Blast Fighting or Ground if Garchomp has Terastallized into a Steel-type. With the Download boost, it also guarantees an OHKO on most Assault Vest Kingambit with Tera Blast Fighting and a 2HKO on non-Sitrus Berry Amoonguss with Ice Beam.

Offensive TR Setter.description:
• Tera Blast is used as strong Normal-type STAB move that offers coverage once Porygon2 Terastallizes. When Tera Blast is paired with a Download Attack boost, Tera Blast becomes a physical move when Porygon2 Terastallizes. This allows you to hit Assault Vest users like Raging Bolt and Rillaboom harder, as well as Pokemon with high base Special Defense such as Flutter Mane. Ice Beam is used as coverage against Landorus and Amoonguss, and Recover is used for longevity, allowing it to set Trick Room up multiple times.

  • With the bulk investment bolstered by the Eviolite, this Porygon2 always survives three Sacred Swords from Chien-Pao, Timid Choice Specs Chi-Yu Overheat, and two Moonblasts from Special Attack Booster Energy Flutter Mane. It also almost always lives a Sword of Ruin Close Combat from Adamant Urshifu.

  • Tera Poison is the main Tera type for Porygon2. It offers resistances to Grass-, Fighting-, and Fairy-type attacks, which are important against Rillaboom, Urshifu, and Flutter Mane, respectively, as well as offering a solid overall defensive typing. Additionally, it allows it to hit Grass- and Fairy-types like Rillaboom, Ogerpon-W, and Tera Fairy Flutter Mane for super effective damage with Tera Blast. Tera Fairy is used to wall Urshifu and hit it and Raging Bolt for super effective damage. Tera Flying is used to hit Grass- and Fighting-types like Urshifu, Ogerpon, and Rillaboom. Additionally, it makes Porygon2 immune to Earthquake from Ursaluna, giving its partner a valuable spread move. Finally, Tera Ghost is used for an immunity to Fighting-type attacks and Fake Out, as well as giving it the ability to hit Flutter Mane.

Smeargle.overview:
• Smeargle is a Pokemon with access to a strong supportive movepool, allowing it to function as a niche supportive option with great role compression.

  • Smeargle works well alongside Urshifu-S, especially Choice Band variants. Along with Follow Me support, Wide Guard can protect Urshifu from common super effective spread moves like Dazzling Gleam and Bleakwind Storm.

  • Smeargle's biggest weakness is its abysmal stats, necessitating the use of Focus Sash in order to give it any survivability. Due to its dreadful Attack stat, it cannot provide any offensive pressure outside of Endeavor, and so it is almost completely reliant on its partner to deal damage.

Support.description:
• Burning Bulwark can be used to dissuade Fake Out and potentially burn physical attackers; however, Spiky Shield can be considered to block certain status effects and bypass opposing Focus Sashes.

  • Decorate can punish passive play in front of Fake Out pressure and should be used alongside Pokemon slower than Smeargle in order to immediately threaten +2 attacks.

  • The invested bulk allows Smeargle to survive a Tachyon Cutter from Iron Crown and almost always survive a Surging Strikes from Urshifu-R after Terastallizing into Grass.

  • Tera Grass is generally preferred to be immune to Spore, though Tera Ghost can be used for a Fake Out immunity.

Entei.overview:
• Entei is a strong offensive threat thanks to its amazing movepool, and access to Sacred Fire and Extreme Speed. Its great defensive stats combined with the immunity to Fake Out and Intimidate given by Inner Focus make it difficult to slow down. When next to Chien-Pao, it can threaten to OHKO on metagame staples Kingambit, Rillaboom, and frailer Flutter Mane sets.

  • As mentioned above, Chien-Pao is a great partner for Entei as Its Sword of Ruin ability helps Entei get KOs more easily. Chien-Pao can also remove Indeedee-F's Psychic Terrain with Ice Spinner, allowing Entei to click Extreme Speed. Another great partner for Entei is Raging Bolt, which, with its powerful Electric-type moves, especially Thunderclap, can pressure foes resistant to Sacred Fire such as Urshifu-R. Ogerpon-W is also a great partner that can redirect Urshifu-R's Surging Strikes or threaten it with a strong Horn Leech.

  • Despite its strengths, Entei struggles against bulky Water- and Fire- types like Urshifu-R, Terastallized Ogerpon-W, Incineroar, and Gouging Fire, which resist Sacred Fire. All of them also either resist Chien-Pao's Ice-type STAB move or can mitigate it and Entei's damage output. Entei also faces issues against Farigiraf, which blocks Extreme Speed.

Bulky Attacker.description:
• Snarl slows down strong special attackers such as Flutter Mane, Raging Bolt, and Iron Crown. Tera Blast can be used instead when using Tera Grass to hit Water-types.

  • Assault Vest helps increase Entei's longevity against special attackers such as Flutter Mane, making Entei even harder to remove taking into account Sacred Fire's burn chance.

  • The EV spread allows Entei to survive a 116 Special Attack Modest Earth Power from Landorus and, when Terastallized, almost always survive Mystic Water Urshifu-R's Tera Water-boosted Surging Strikes, the rest of the EVs are used to maximize its damage output.

  • Tera Grass provides resistances to Water- and Ground- types like Urshifu-R and Landorus, as well as granting a Spore immunity. Tera Normal boosts Entei's Extreme Speed power while also removing its original weaknesses.

Tyranitar.comments:
Teambuilding

  • Tyranitar excels at complementing powerhouses like Gholdengo by checking its threats such as Kingambit, Incineroar, and Hisuian Typhlosion, as well as disrupting weather-reliant Pokemon like Pelipper and Archaludon. Tyranitar appreciates redirection support like Amoonguss and Magmar to handle Fighting-type attacks like Close Combat from Sneasler and works well with Trick Room balance composition due to its mediocre Speed tier.
  • Tyranitar and Gholdengo complement each other, with Gholdengo checking threats such as Rillaboom, Amoonguss, and Archaludon in sand while appreciating Tyranitar's coverage options that handle Fire-types such as Volcarona, Talonflame, and Incineroar that Gholdengo is weak to. Amoonguss is an exceptional support option, redirecting Fighting-type attacks like Close Combat and Drain Punch from Sneasler and Annihilape, respectively. Due to its average Speed tier, Tyranitar excels in both Tailwind and Trick Room. Trick Room setters such as Porygon2 and Sinistcha allow Amoonguss and Tyranitar to take advantage of their lower Speed stat to move before their foes. Meanwhile, Talonflame provides Tailwind to help Tyranitar and its faster partners like Gholdengo move first. Rillaboom checks troublesome Water-types like Basculegion and Primarina while weakening Garchomp's Earthquake and offering passive recovery thanks to its Grassy Terrain.
  • Tyranitar is especially susceptible to Garchomp and Archaludon, lacking the means to outdamage them while being weak to their coverage options like the latter's Body Press. Tera Steel Gholdengo threatens to 2HKO Tyranitar with Make it Rain, while faster physical attackers like Basculegion and Rillaboom check it. Redirectors like Amoonguss help to an extent, while speed control in the form of Trick Room can help turn the tide of the battle. Offensive partners like Garchomp check Archaludon and Gholdengo with Stomping Tantrum and Earthquake, while Primarina threatens Garchomp with Moonblast.

Strategy Comments

  • As a weather setter and special tank, Tyranitar excels at threatening checks to powerhouses like Gholdengo and Garchomp, weakening opposing weather teams such as rain and sun, as well as checking hard Trick Room teams utilizing Armarouge, Torkoal, and Indeedee-F. Tyranitar also immediately threatens offensive Pokemon such as Choice Specs Hisuian Typhlosion or Talonflame and can fill the role of a strong defensive backbone of the team.
  • Tyranitar is a strong lead into offensive strategies, ideally to get rid of Talonflame or Hisuian Typhlosion to help its partners like Gholdengo for late-game dominance. Against rain teams, a well-timed switch-in can force Archaludon to waste a turn charging its Electro Shot while threatening Pelipper with Rock Slide. Additionally, setting up sand early can be useful in breaking Focus Sash on common metagame threats such as Sneasler. Tyranitar's efficiency increases with the help of speed control like Trick Room, often provided by Porygon2, where it is safe to move first and secure KOs.
  • Gholdengo, Annihilape, Archaludon, and Garchomp threaten to either OHKO or deal a massive amount of damage to Tyranitar with their STAB moves. It is advisable to keep Tyranitar in the back until the threat is removed or disrupted, either via support options like Amoonguss and Incineroar or by utilizing offensive Pokemon like Volcarona, Gholdengo, and Garchomp.

Sand Tank.description:
• Boasting excellent defenses and a powerful Attack stat with decent coverage options, Tyranitar functions as a weather-setting tank thanks to its ability, checking meta threats such as Pelipper, Volcarona, and Kingambit.
  • Tera Blast Flying allows Tyranitar to hit Sneasler, Rillaboom, and Amoonguss super effectively, while Low Kick deals massive damage to Hydreigon and OHKOes Kingambit and opposing Tyranitar.
  • Assault Vest further amplifies Tyranitar Special Defense, working in tandem with sand to bolster its special bulk to enormous proportions.
  • Tera Flying sheds Tyranitar's weaknesses to Fighting- and Ground-type attacks like Sneasler's Close Combat and Garchomp's Earthquake while providing additional coverage in the form of Tera Blast to hit Fighting-types like Sneasler and Grass-types like Rillaboom, Amoonguss, and Tera Grass Archaludon.
  • The Speed EVs help outspeed Sneasler in Tailwind while still having sufficient bulk to withstand Choice Specs Tera Steel Make it Rain from Gholdengo comfortably.

Pelipper.comments:
Teambuilding

  • Pelipper excels in teams capable of taking advantage of Drizzle while also having sufficient defensive options to switch around to regain control of the weather late-game.
  • Archaludon, with its signature move Electro Shot, works exceptionally well in rain, and it provides a defensive backbone to the team thanks to its immense bulk and ability, capable of switching into threats such as Tyranitar's Rock Slide and Maushold's Population Bomb. It quickly becomes an offensive threat once it starts stacking up Electro Shot boosts in rain.
  • Basculegion-M's ability Swift Swim makes it desirable on rain teams both as an early-game powerhouse with its fast rain-boosted Wave Crash and as a late-game sweeper with Last Respects. Its immense Speed and power help it form a well-rounded balanced core with Archaludon and Pelipper, taking on threats such as Garchomp and Gholdengo, while Pelipper threatens the Grass-types that resists Wave Crash like Amoonguss and Rillaboom with Hurricane.
  • Pelipper struggles against opposing weather setters like Tyranitar, which not only tanks Pelipper's STAB moves in sand but also breaks its Focus Sash with sand chip damage and KOs it with Rock Slide. Archaludon takes advantage of Pelipper's rain to fire off Electro Shots as well as completely walling Pelipper's STAB attacks. Amoonguss is an excellent disruptive option, taking advantage of its bulk to survive attacks like Knock Off from Tyranitar and Draco Meteor from Archaludon and put the aforementioned threats to sleep with Spore. Basculegion-M is a great check against Tyranitar as well, outspeeding and OHKOing it with Wave Crash.

Strategy Comments

  • As a rain setter, Pelipper is often used to enable Archaludon snowball with Electro Shots while handling threats like Amoonguss with Hurricane. Speed control with Tailwind is desirable due to Archaludon's slow Speed, and it helps tremendously against balance archetypes.
  • Pelipper is often lead with Basculegion-M or Archaludon to immediately take advantage of rain, provided the opposing team lacks a method to change the weather. A more flexible approach would be to lead the weather-reliant Pokemon like Archaludon and prepare Pelipper as a switch-in to swiftly take control of the game with a well-timed weather change. It is pivotal to keep Pelipper intact for late-game weather control, as lack of such could potentially end up severely weakening the board and result in a loss of momentum.
  • Rivaling weather setters like Tyranitar and Alolan Ninetales threaten Pelipper's rain. It's advisable to preserve Pelipper and switch it in to thwart Aurora Veil setups from Alolan Ninetales, while Archaludon or Basculegion-M should take out Tyranitar first. Opposing Archaludon can end up being a powerful threat due to being capable of walling Pelipper while taking advantage of its rain. The ideal option here would be to use Amoonguss to force it to Terastallize into a Grass-type, and then have Pelipper deal a massive amount of damage to it with Hurricane.

Weather Setter.description:
• Pelipper functions as a weather setter thanks to Drizzle, enabling powerhouses like Archaludon and Basculegion-M to dish out enormous damage as well as providing support in the form of speed control or Wide Guard. Its Flying- and Water-type STAB options combined with its decent Speed help Pelipper to fill in the role of an attacker as well, taking advantage of its own rain to buff its offensive options.
  • Weather Ball is a flexible attack that gains a STAB boost in rain while providing decent coverage under opposing weather like sun. Tailwind provides speed control for the team, whereas Wide Guard protects the team from Gholdengo's Make it Rain, Ursaluna-B's Hyper Voice, Expanding Force in Psychic Terrain, and Garchomp's Earthquake.
  • Focus Sash allows Pelipper to survive an attack due to the set's frailty, increasing its long-term value as a weather setter and allowing it to get an extra attack off.
  • Tera Stellar further boosts its damage, allowing Pelipper to OHKO Amoonguss and Annihilape with Hurricane and Tera Normal Ursaluna-B and Assault Vest Incineroar with rain-boosted Weather Ball. Meanwhile, Tera Ghost provides an immunity to Fake Out, enabling an early Tailwind uninterrupted while keeping Focus Sash intact.
  • A maximized Special Attack stat with a Modest nature secures an OHKO on Incineroar with rain-boosted Weather Ball and on Amoonguss with Tera Stellar Hurricane, while a Timid nature can be opted for faster speed control and securing KOs on weakened Pokemon, and it comes in handy in rain mirror matches.

Rain Setter.description:
• Pelipper can use Wide Guard over Protect to block spread move, most notably Iron Crown's Expanding Force. Pelipper utilizes Weather Ball to obtain strong boosted STAB, threatening Incineroar and Landorus.

  • Pelipper utilizes Rocky Helmet to provide useful chip damage against Fake Out users, Ice Spinner Chien-Pao, and Urshifu-R, but can use Focus Sash for survivability or Damp Rock to extend rain for slower teams.

  • When using Focus Sash, Pelipper should use an alternative spread of 4 HP / 252 SpA / 252 Spe with a Modest or Timid nature instead, foregoing bulk.

  • The EV spread helps Pelipper survive a Choice Specs Flutter Mane's Moonblast and almost always a Miracle Seed Rillaboom's Wood Hammer. The Speed investment allows Pelipper to outspeed Ogerpon when in Tailwind.

  • Tera Steel helps Pelipper gain resistances to strong threats like Rillaboom and Flutter Mane, giving it a turn to set Tailwind or click Hurricane. Tera Flying can be used to boost Pelipper's damage output and, when fully invested in Special Attack, threaten Amoonguss for an OHKO. Tera Ghost makes Pelipper immune to common moves, being Fake Out and Extreme Speed.

Torkoal.overview:
• Torkoal is a premier offensive Pokemon seen on Trick Room teams thanks to its great STAB moves, fantastic ability, and good defenses. Its low Speed also makes it faster than most of the tier when in Trick Room, and it has great matchups into Pokemon like Amoonguss

  • Some of Torkoal's strongest partners are Trick Room setters like Cresselia and Farigiraf, which can help set up Trick Room and protect it from damage with Ally Switch and Armor Tail, respectively. Torkoal also pairs well with other Pokemon that benefit from Trick Room like Ursaluna-B and Iron Hands, which can threaten neutral damage onto most of the tier, notably threatening Pokemon like Raging Bolt and Tera Water Ogerpon-W, respectively.

  • Torkoal struggles against bulky Pokemon that resist Fire like Raging Bolt, Incineroar, as well as Tera Water Ogerpon-W, and Assault Vest Rillaboom, as they can withstand its boosted Eruptions and burn Trick Room turns, making partners like Ursaluna-B, Amoonguss, and Rillaboom appreciated.

Trick Room Sweeper.description:
• Earth Power hits foes that resist Fire like Entei, Incineroar, Arcanine-Hisui, and Raging Bolt.

  • Charcoal boosts the damage of Torkoal's Fire-type moves, letting it OHKO Assault Vest Kingambit.

  • Tera Fire further bolsters Torkoal's Fire-type moves, letting it even 2HKO foes that resist Fire like Raging Bolt, Chi-Yu, and Tera Water Amoonguss.

Metagross.overview:
• Metagross serves as a good defensive Pokemon on balance teams thanks to its great defenses that are bolstered even further by Assault Vest, its good ability, and its nice defensive typing against foes like Raging Bolt and Iron Crown. Its access to coverage and high Attack stat make it appreciated as an offensive threat too.

  • Metagross can pair well with offensive Pokemon like Flutter Mane and Landorus, which can help deal with the Dark-, Ghost-, and Fire-types that threaten it like Urshifu-S, Gholdengo, and Entei. Another excellent partner can be Ogerpon-W, which has great synergy with Metagross, being able to deal with Ground-types like Landorus and redirect Sucker Punch from Chien-Pao, while Metagross can help Ogerpon-W against Rillaboom and Raging Bolt.

  • Before Terastallizing, Metagross can be overwhelmed by Pokemon like Kingambit, Chi-Yu, and Entei, making defensive partners like Amoonguss and Incineroar appreciated. Rillaboom can also be a good teammate for Metagross, providing it with passive recovery and utility via Grassy Terrain and Fake Out, respectively.

Bulky Attacker.description:
• Stomping Tantrum lets Metagross hit Fire- and Steel-types likeIncineroar, Entei, and Kingambit and can also help against targets like Raging Bolt. Stomping Tantrum in particular is important to hit Steel-types like Iron Crown, as they wall Metagross's STAB moves.

  • Bullet Punch can be used to help pick off weakened foes like Flutter Mane.

  • With an Assault Vest, Metagross can almost always survive Earth Power from Landorus

  • With the given EV spread, Metagross almost always survives Icicle Crash from Adamant Chien-Pao when using Tera Dragon, and it is only 3HKOed by -1 Adamant Chien-Pao's Sacred Sword when using Tera Steel. The Speed EVs let it outspeed -1 Adamant Landorus-T, as well as Roaring Moon and Adamant Chien-Pao when in Tailwind.

  • Tera Dragon lets Metagross handle Fire-types like Chi-Yu and Entei in a pinch, and it can also be useful to deal with Water-types like Ogerpon-W and Choice Scarf Urshifu-R. Tera Steel helps remove its weakness against Pokemon like Kingambit, Flutter Mane, and Chien-Pao, and it can also give Bullet Punch a chance to OHKO offensive Flutter Mane.

Registeel.overview:
• With an extremely high Defense stat and access to the coveted IronPress combination, Registeel serves the role of the format's late-game sweeper. Steel is an incredibly good typing defensively, and Clear Body stops Intimidate from the likes of Incineroar, which could otherwise prevent the OHKO on Flutter Mane with Heavy Slam.

  • Registeel fits best on balance teams that feature its favorite partners. Incineroar and Amoonguss can slow down the pace of the game, Latias provides crucial speed control in Tailwind, and Rillaboom's Grassy Surge and Fake Out is appreciated by Registeel. Additionally, Latias and Rillaboom threaten Urshifu-R. Similarly, Raging Bolt is also a good Registeel partner, being the premier Urshifu-R counter in the format.

  • Notable good matchups for Registeel include Rillaboom and Ogerpon-W, both of which get cleanly 2HKOed by Body Press after a single Iron Defense boost. Kingambit also does poorly against Registeel, as Swords Dance can be mitigated by Iron Defense and Body Press hits Kingambit very hard if it does not Terastallize.

  • However, not all physical attackers are helpless against the IronPress Registeel. Both Urshifu formes can pose a threat, depending on Registeel's choice of Tera type. Chien-Pao can threaten heavy damage with Sacred Sword if Registeel has not used Terastallization. Gholdengo is also a hard counter to Registeel, as it is immune to Body Press and resists Heavy Slam while also being able to set up with Nasty Plot and break through Registeel's high bulk.

IronPress.description:
• Heavy Slam allows Registeel to hit opposing Ghost-types like Flutter Mane. 52 Attack EVs allow Heavy Slam to OHKO bulky Flutter Mane.

  • Leftovers keeps it healthy throughout the game, with Protect providing additional turns of recovery.

  • Tera Water is the standard Tera Type for Registeel, allowing it to resist Urshifu-R's Surging Strikes and being a generally good defensive typing. However, with the rise of Urshifu-S, Tera Fairy is a viable option to resist Wicked Blow and Fighting-type moves while also being neutral into the majority of the metagame. Be careful using this, however as Teratallized Urshifu-R threatens a 2HKO with Surging Strikes, and Landorus can easily pin you with Earth Power and Sludge Bomb.

  • The Special Defense investment allows Registeel to almost always survive Timid Earth Power from Landorus. The rest of the Defense EVs along with an Impish nature maximize its damage output.

Latias.overview:
• Latias is an exceptional Tailwind setter thanks to its great bulk, defensive typing, Levitate, and solid Speed. It also checks common threats such as Landorus and Urshifu-R.

  • Assault Vest Kingambit is a great partner, beating most of Latias's counters like Flutter Mane, Gholdengo, and, to an extent, Incineroar. It also makes great use of Tailwind, and Latias beats most of its counters as well.

  • Latias can be very tough to remove especially if it Terastallizes into a Poison-type, which, when combined with Levitate, has only one weakness and many valuable resistances. This becomes extra apparent when using Recover, which lets it clean up late-game when positioned well, especially if Mist Ball gets some Special Attack drops.

Bulky Tailwind Setter.description:
• Ice Beam is great coverage in general and very important for OHKOing Landorus, one of Latias's best and most important matchups.

  • Rocky Helmet lets Latias punish common and important moves like Fake Out and U-turn. It also breaks Chien-Pao's Focus Sash if it opts to run Ice Spinner and heavily discourages the prevalent Urshifu-R from attacking it.

  • The Speed EVs allow it to outspeed max Speed Landorus, the Special Attack EVs let it OHKO Urshifu-R and Landorus more consistently, and the rest of the EVs are used to optimize its bulk.

  • Tera Poison, when paired with Levitate, makes Latias very difficult to break, as Psychic-types, besides opposing Latias, are not common, and the Poison typing offers resistances to many relevant offensive types, the most important of which being Fairy, because of Flutter Mane.

Garchomp.comments:
Teambuilding

  • Garchomp fits well onto a variety of teams. It isn't capable of surviving multiple strong attacks, so it relies on partners that allow it to attack without receiving a lot of damage in return. Priority Tailwind setters like Talonflame and Whimsicott are great partners, and they both provide additional Taunt support to disrupt Trick Room setters like Porygon2. Fake Out users like Incineroar disrupt foes for Garchomp. Incineroar additionally provides damage reduction via Intimidate and Parting Shot. Garchomp also works well on balance teams featuring Porygon2, as Garchomp threatens Gholdengo and Incineroar, both of which Porygon2 and its common partners struggle to damage. Garchomp additionally performs well on beatdown teams featuring Dragonite, as Garchomp can freely attack with Earthquake without damaging it.
  • Amoonguss and Vivillon provide redirection and sleep support; Amoonguss is bulkier and has a more consistent way of putting foes to sleep, while Vivillon is faster and is immune to Garchomp's Earthquake. Garchomp pairs well with Porygon2; Porygon2 setting Trick Room can allow Garchomp to attack before threats like Dragapult. Porygon2 additionally deals significant damage to Grass- and Flying-types with Ice Beam and can comfortably survive Earthquake while regaining the lost HP with Recover. Dragonite also synergizes well with Garchomp. Dragonite can deal strong damage with Extreme Speed, allowing Garchomp to secure KOs with Earthquake and removes Grass-types like Rillaboom, which Garchomp struggles to KO, with Tera Blast Flying.
  • Garchomp is threatened by Dragon-, Fairy-, and Ice-type attacks like Dragon Darts and Outrage from Dragapult, Moonblast from Clefable, and Blizzard from Alolan Ninetales. All of these attacks can be switched into by Steel-type partners such as Gholdengo and Kingambit. Garchomp also struggles to damage Flying-types like Pelipper, especially when it isn't using Rock Slide, so a partner like Alolan Ninetales easily threatens Flying-types with Blizzard and Freeze-Dry.

Strategy Comments

  • As a glass cannon, Garchomp's task is to deal as much damage as possible uninterrupted. Garchomp performs best when it outspeeds its foes and when it is supported by redirection, allowing Garchomp to attack freely.
  • Garchomp excels at being an early-game sweeper as well as a late-game cleaner. Garchomp primarily attacks using Earthquake to damage both foes. It uses Stomping Tantrum when Garchomp's partner is vulnerable to the damage from Earthquake or when Grassy Terrain is active. Dragon Claw and Rock Slide are used to damage foes that resist Earthquake and Stomping Tantrum.
  • Dragapult outspeeds and threatens Garchomp. To beat Dragapult, Garchomp needs Tailwind or Trick Room support, allowing it to threaten Dragapult with Dragon Claw before it attacks. A partner Kingambit can also survive an attack from Dragapult and threaten it in return with Kowtow Cleave or before Dragapult attacks with Sucker Punch. Rillaboom is also troublesome for Garchomp, as Grassy Terrain weakens the damage of Earthquake. Garchomp is very reliant on partners like Talonflame and Dragonite to remove Rillaboom, as it struggles to deal threatening spread damage when Grassy Terrain is active.

Glass Cannon.description:
• Garchomp utilizes its high Attack and good Speed to outspeed and greatly weaken foes with powerful spread damage.
  • Using both Stomping Tantrum and Earthquake allows Garchomp to switch between dealing single-target and spread damage. Earthquake, however, is used most effectively when Garchomp's partner is able to use Protect or is immune to Ground-type attacks. Rock Slide is most commonly used by Choice Band Garchomp to threaten Flying-types like Talonflame and Pelipper. It is used as an alternative spread damage attack that doesn't affect Garchomp's partner and is unhindered by Grassy Terrain set by a partner Rillaboom.
  • Life Orb boosts Garchomp's damage, allowing it to threaten an OHKO onto +1 Defense Sneasler with Stomping Tantrum or Earthquake and Dragonite with Dragon Claw. Clear Amulet is used to block Intimidate and Parting Shot from Incineroar. Choice Band provides a greater damage increase than Life Orb, allowing it to threaten an OHKO onto Gholdengo with Stomping Tantrum or Earthquake at the cost of being unable to switch between attacks. The item choice greatly affects Garchomp. Life Orb and Choice Band sets are subject to having its Attack dropped by Incineroar cycling Intimidate and Parting Shot, while the damage from Clear Amulet sets is less.
  • Tera Steel inverts Garchomp's weaknesses to Fairy-, Dragon-, and Ice-type attacks such as Moonblast from Clefable, Outrage from Dragonite, and Blizzard from Alolan Ninetales; additionally, it allows Garchomp to resist Choice Specs-boosted Tera Steel Make It Rain from Gholdengo. Tera Ground increases the damage of Stomping Tantrum and Earthquake, allowing Garchomp to OHKO Gholdengo. Tera Fire provides similar resistances as Tera Steel while not granting a weakness to Fighting-type attacks, and it provides an immunity to burn.

Gallade.comments:
Teambuilding

  • Gallade isn't a particularly bulky Pokemon, so it is often paired with partners more capable of setting up Trick Room while Gallade threatens foes that threaten its partners. Gallade also can be paired with redirection that allows it to set up Trick Room.
  • Hatterene pairs well with Gallade, as it is more capable of setting Trick Room up thanks to its bulk, while Gallade threatens foes such as Incineroar and Kingambit that Hatterene struggles to damage in return. Hatterene additionally threatens physically defensive foes that Gallade struggles to OHKO such as Amoonguss and provides powerful spread damage with Dazzling Gleam, which complements Gallade when it fails to achieve an OHKO. Indeedee-F provides redirection, allowing Gallade to safely set up Trick Room. It is additionally capable of setting up Trick Room itself while Gallade provides Wide Guard support. Indeedee-F setting up Psychic Terrain further supports Gallade by preventing Fake Out disruption and increasing the damage of Psycho Cut.
  • Amoonguss threatens to put Gallade to sleep with Spore, often forcing it to Terastallize into a Grass-type. A partner Torkoal threatens Amoonguss with Eruption and Weather Ball and outspeeds it while Trick Room is active. Gholdengo is difficult for Gallade to remove and threatens to deal significant damage with its STAB attacks. Torkoal and Ursaluna can survive Gholdengo's attacks and threaten it in return with Eruption and Headlong Rush. Basculegion-M threatens Gallade with its STAB attacks, so a partner Kingambit is capable of surviving these attacks and threatening it with Sucker Punch and Kowtow Cleave.

Strategy Comments

  • Gallade is a sweeper and a support Pokemon for Trick Room teams. It performs best early-game by removing threats preventing Trick Room from being set up or setting up Trick Room itself.
  • Gallade should always be led with a partner capable of setting Trick Room such as Hatterene or Indeedee-F. If paired with Hatterene, Gallade can be used to remove threats such as Kingambit and Incineroar. When facing Gholdengo, it can use Wide Guard to protect Hatterene from Make It Rain. If Gallade is paired with Indeedee-F, it can set Trick Room as Indeedee-F redirects attacks with Follow Me. However, there may be situations where Indeedee-F can be used to set up Trick Room itself while Gallade removes an opposing threat like Kingambit. Gallade can also use Wide Guard while Indeedee-F sets up Trick Room, protecting both Pokemon from attacks like Eruption from Hisuian Typhlosion.
  • Gallade is checked by Ghost-types and threatened by their attacks like Shadow Ball and Last Respects. As a result, Gallade is very reliant on redirection from Indeedee-F or switching to it if Indeedee-F is not lead. Gallade also relies on Kingambit to threaten them.
  • Foes with Imprison like Indeedee-M disrupt Trick Room teams and are often difficult for Gallade to remove, so it relies on partners like Ursaluna and Kingambit for this. If the opponent pivots around to stall out Trick Room turns, getting KOs while Trick Room is active becomes difficult for Gallade and its partners. To mitigate this, overwhelming the foes with powerful attacks from teammates like Ursaluna helps to reduce the effectiveness of the switches.

Offensive Trick Room Sweeper.description:
• Gallade is an offensive threat thanks to Sharpness and its ability to set Trick Room up for itself and its partners.
  • Sacred Sword ignores the Defense boosts of foes like Archaludon and Dondozo. Psycho Cut is used as a consistent Psychic-type STAB move that is also boosted by Sharpness. Its damage can be boosted further by a partner's Psychic Terrain. Wide Guard protects Gallade and its partner from spread attacks such as Make It Rain and Eruption.
  • Clear Amulet prevents Gallade's Attack from being hindered by Intimidate and Parting Shot, allowing it to always deal threatening damage to metagame staples such as Incineroar.
  • Tera Grass provides Gallade with an immunity to Spore, Sleep Powder, and Rage Powder while allowing it to resist Electro Shot from Archaludon. Tera Fire, unlike Tera Grass, removes Gallade's weakness to Flying-type attacks such as Hurricane from Pelipper without gaining a weakness to Poison-type attacks such as Dire Claw from Sneasler, and it also allows Gallade to resist Make It Rain from Gholdengo. Tera Fire additionally provides an immunity to burn.

Trick Room Abuser.description:
• Psycho Cut and Sacred Sword are the highest base power moves that take advantage of Sharpness.

  • The Defense EVs allow Gallade to survive a Wicked Blow and Surging Strikes from Urshifu-S and Urshifu-R, respectively.

  • Tera Grass allows Gallade to ignore powder moves from Amoonguss, a common Trick Room counter, and resist common physical attackers such as Rillaboom. Alternatively, Tera Fire can be used to resist common anti-Trick Room leads such as Chi-Yu and Flutter Mane, as well as giving Gallade a Fairy resist.

Heatran.overview:
• Heatran is a niche bulky offensive threat thanks to its solid stats and great typing, bolstered by Flash Fire. This makes Heatran have an incredible matchup against most of the metagame, such as Flutter Mane and Gholdengo.

  • Rillaboom is a great partner for Heatran, as it resists Heatran's prominent weaknesses, while also hitting Pokemon like Ogerpon-W and Urshifu-R for huge damage. Heatran also pairs well with Ogerpon-W, which supports Heatran with Follow Me, as well as threatening Urshifu-R and Landorus.

  • Although Heatran resists a lot of attacks with its typing, it's weak to both of the Urshifu formes, Ogerpon-W, Landorus, and Iron Hands. Heatran also faces tough Fire- and Steel- competition, especially with Incineroar.

Bulky Attacker.description:
• The combination of Heatran's STAB moves, Heat Wave and Flash Cannon, can hit a lot of Pokemon in the metagame super-effectively, while Earth Power is a good coverage move that can hit Pokemon that resist Heatran's STAB combination, like Incineroar. Magma Storm is also another option as a Fire-type attack, as it traps the opponent, which works well with Leftovers.

  • Leftovers is a good item choice for Heatran, as it can live two Shadow Balls from Flutter Mane with a Special Attack-Booster Energy, and with Rillaboom's Grassy Surge, Heatran can constantly restore HP. Life Orb can increase Heatran's damage output, making it more of a threat.

  • 228 HP, 84 Defense EVs, and 20 Special Defense EVs allow Heatran to take an Ivy Cudgel from Ogerpon-W, almost always survives a Sludge Bomb from Landorus after Heatran Terastallizes and Life Orb recoil, and finally, with 20 Speed EVs, Heatran outspeeds both Urshifu formes after a Speed drop.

  • Tera Grass is an excellent Tera type for Heatran, allowing it to resist Water- and Ground-type moves from the likes of Pokemon like Urshifu-R and Landorus. Tera Fairy can allow Heatran to resist Urshifu-S's STAB moves and be a neutral type against the metagame.

Cresselia.overview:
• Cresselia shines in VGC as an incredibly bulky Trick Room setter with access to Lunar Blessing. Cresselia is a great check to Amoonguss and Urshifu-R, nullifying Spore with Lunar Blessing and pressuring the latter with a 2HKO.

  • Cresselia's strongest partner is Ursaluna, as it's a strong Trick Room sweeper that appreciates Lunar Blessing negating the burn chip damage. Cresselia's Levitate also allows Ursaluna to freely click Earthquake. Cresselia also appreciates Pokemon like Amoonguss and Iron Hands, which help get up Trick Room and act as threats under Trick Room themselves.

  • Cresselia struggles against Incineroar, as Fake Out can allow Incineroar's partner to get off another hit, which can be the difference between setting up Trick Room and not. Cresselia also faces issues against Farigiraf, which can reverse or Imprison Trick Room. Tornadus can also prove to be difficult, as Taunt prevents Trick Room from going up and takes advantage of Cresselia's passivity.

Trick Room Support.description:
• Cresselia uses Moonblast to hit more of the metagame for super effective damage, including Urshifu-S, while Ice Beam can be used to threaten the Landorus formes and Dragonite. Cresselia may opt for Psychic for the extra power before Terastallization.

  • Helping Hand allows Cresselia to more actively support its partners, especially Ursaluna and its Earthquake. Cresselia can use Ally Switch to provide game-deciding mind games and a way to protect its partners in a pinch.

  • Cressellia uses Safety Goggles to protect itself from Amoonguss's Spore and be able to consistently protect its teammates with Lunar Blessing.

  • The EV spread allows Cresselia to almost always survive two Mystic Water Surging Strikes from Urshifu-R, and always avoid the 2HKO from Choice Specs Flutter Mane's Moonblast.

  • Tera Fairy is the most consistent for Cresselia, as it provides a resistance to the common Dark-type moves such as Urshifu-S's Wicked Blow or Kingambit's Kowtow Cleave, as well as gaining STAB on Moonblast. Tera Poison is a generally good defensive typing further bolstered by Levitate, and it provides key resistances to Flutter Mane's Moonblast and Rillaboom's STAB moves.

Whimsicott.comments:
Teambuilding

  • Whimsicott generally works well on hyper offensive teams that appreciate its ability to provide speed control and shut down opposing setup threats with Encore. Pokemon that have middling or high Speed tiers and strong offenses pair especially well with Whimsicott. Whimsicott can also work well on sun-centric teams, utilizing its ability to overwrite Pelipper's Drizzle with Sunny Day to maintain speed and weather control.

  • Whimsicott pairs especially well with strong special attackers, namely Hisuian Typhlosion, Glimmora, Power Herb Archaludon, Gholdengo, and Garchomp. Their middling Speed tiers benefit greatly from Tailwind, and Hisuian Typhlosion in particular also appreciates Whimsicott's ability to set sun, boosting its Eruption further while mitigating its Water weakness. Annihilape can be used on some teams that want to employ Beat Up strategies, which can also be effective.

  • Whimsicott can struggle into teams that can handle its partner's offensive onslaught or mitigate Whimsicott's Tailwind Speed advantage. However, by changing up Whimsicott's partner, it can break through some defensive cores that may stop one pairing but not the other. For example, while Incineroar may be able to beat Whimsicott and Hisuian Typhlosion, it loses to Meteor Beam Glimmora. Since Whimsicott generally pairs with strong, fast offensive threats, its playstyle is very vunerable to Trick Room, especially teams that have Psychic Terrain, which blocks Whimsicott's Prankster Encore. Due to this, Whimsicott generally likes to pair with Incineroar to shut down Trick Room teams while also allowing Whimsicott's frailer partners to pivot in safely.

Strategy Comments

  • Whimsicott exists as a support Pokemon, providing speed control through Prankster Tailwind and amplifying its partner's damage output through Helping Hand or Sunny Day.
  • Whimsicott is almost always a lead Pokemon, with a hard-hitting partner that takes advantage of its Tailwind support. It almost always wants to be clicking Tailwind to gain the Speed advantage immediately, unless it is facing a Trick Room team that can turn that advantage on its head. Against bulkier cores that may not have speed control or care about moving first, Whimsicott may choose to use Helping Hand or Sunny Day to try to break through those cores with its partner's sheer power.
  • Whimsicott is mainly weak to strong priority that can take it out before it can set Tailwind, mainly Tera Normal Extreme Speed from Dragonite and Brave Bird from Talonflame. Pokemon that can stomach many hits and slow down the level of offense coming from Whimsicott's side can also be a problem, since Whimsicott is so frail that it can usually only afford to set Tailwind or Sunny Day once. By choosing certain partners for Whimsicott, this matchup problem can be turned on its head. Pokemon such as Glimmora can beat common counters to Whimsicott, including Talonflame, Dragonite, and Incineroar. Pokemon that block priority moves can also support Whimsicott, such as Indeedee with Psychic Terrain and Farigiraf with Armor Tail.

Tailwind Support.description:
• Whimsicott is a staple on hyper offense teams due to its ability to set Tailwind with its Prankster ability. Whimsicott also provides valuable support to its team through the use of Encore to disrupt opposing strategies or Helping Hand and Sunny Day to boost its partner's damage output.
  • Encore is generally preferred to be able to pin opposing Pokemon into positions where they cannot use Protect, dissuade setup, and lock opposing Pokemon into moves such as Fake Out or Tailwind. Helping Hand is the preferred last move on Whimsicott for most teams because it provides a damage boost to any of Whimsicott's partners. Sunny Day is used on certain hyper offense teams to boost Hisuian Typhlosion's Eruption and provide weather control against Pelipper. Protect is almost always used on Focus Sash sets to block Fake Out without the need to Terastallize into a Ghost-type. Beat Up is specifically used with Annihilape to boost its Rage Fist; this, in conjunction with Tailwind, makes it into a threat as quickly as possible.
  • Covert Cloak is generally preferred on Whimsicott to block the effects of Fake Out, allowing Whimsicott to get Tailwind off without having to run Protect. However, Focus Sash is sometimes used on teams that want Whimsicott's support on the field for longer. Focus Sash also allows Whimsicott to set Tailwind in front of Talonflame, which would otherwise KO Whimsicott before it can set Tailwind with Brave Bird in conjunction with Gale Wings.
  • Tera Water can be used to give Covert Cloak Whimsicott an extra turn on the field against common Pokemon such as Incineroar, Hisuian Typhlosion, and Gholdengo, though it must watch out for Rillaboom's now supereffective priority Grassy Glide. Tera Ghost gives Whimsicott an immunity to common priority moves, namely Fake Out and Extreme Speed and is usually seen on Focus Sash sets, as they are susceptible to Fake Out. Tera Fire offers similar defensive benefits to Tera Water while still resisting Rillaboom's Grassy Glide after Terastallization. However, Tera Fire makes Whimsicott weak to common moves such a as Primarina's Liquid Voice Hyper Voice and Pelipper's Weather Ball under rain. Tera Dark is a niche option on Focus Sash sets that gives Whimsicott an immunity to opposing Prankster moves from the likes of Murkrow and opposing Whimsicott.
  • The first spread for Covert Cloak Whimsicott maximizes HP investment over damage output to live attacks that would otherwise prevent it from setting Tailwind. Focus Sash sets, on the other hand, invest more into Special Attack.

Sun Setter.description:
• Moonblast keeps Whimsicott from being passive and hits threats like Raging Bolt and Urshifu-S for super effective damage.

  • Whimsicott can opt for Beat Up instead, allowing it to trigger Annihilape's Rage Fist and Terrakion's Justified ability.

  • Sunny Day activates Pokemon like Flutter Mane and Raging Bolts's abilities, making them more potent threats, as well as weakening Urshifu-R and Ogerpon-W.

  • The fourth move slot is customizable; Fake Tears allows Whimsicott to weaken Pokemon for partners like Flutter Mane and Landorus, Encore locks foes into unfavorable moves like Protect and Fake Out, Taunt helps shut down more passive Pokemon like Amoonguss and opposing Whimsicott.

  • The EV spread allows Whimsicott to live Tornadus's Bleakwind Storm and outspeed Maximum Speed Tornadus.

  • Tera Water grants Whimsicott valuable resistances to Fire-, Ice-, and Steel-types like Incineroar, Chien-Pao, and Kingambit while generally being a great defensive typing.

  • Covert Cloak allows Whimsicott to be immune to Fake Out.

Offensive Utility.description:
• Protect is valuable for dealing with Fake Out, but it does not allow to fit Sunny Day.

  • Tera Ghost makes Whimsicott immune to common priority moves like Fake Out and Extreme Speed as well as providing a resistance to Poison-type moves like Landorus' Sludge Bomb.

  • Focus Sash allows Whimsicott to have another chance to set up Tailwind or support its team later on in the game, as its mediocre defensive stats and plethora of weaknesses otherwise leave it potentially OHKOd by most Pokemon in the metagame.

  • Note that if Whimsicott is running Beat Up, an EV spread of 252 HP / 4 Def / 252 Spe with a Jolly Nature is more optimal.

Amoonguss.overview:
• Amoonguss excels as a support Pokemon thanks to its great defensive typing and toolkit. Regenerator gives Amoonguss longevity and allows it to constantly answer Urshifu-R, Iron Hands, and Flutter Mane with Rage Powder throughout the game.

  • Amoonguss appreciates Incineroar allowing it to pivot to activate Regenerator, as well as the Intimidate and Fake Out support Incineroar provides after pivoting in. Incineroar also helps Amoonguss by pressuring the powder-immune Grass-types and weakening threats like Chien-Pao and opposing Incineroar, while Amoonguss can keep it healthy through Pollen Puff and protect it from Pokemon like Urshifu-R and Flutter Mane in return.

  • Amoonguss also pairs well with frail offensive Pokemon like Urshifu-R, which threatens problematic Fire-types like Incineroar and Entei. Amoonguss can also protect Urshifu-R from Flutter Mane and Raging Bolt through Rage Powder.

  • Amoonguss struggles against Pokemon like Entei and Chi-Yu, which threaten to OHKO it, as well as Grass-types like Rillaboom or opposing Amoonguss who can ignore it. Ogerpon-W with Follow Me can be an issue because it restricts Amoonguss from putting foes to sleep.

Bulky Support.description:
• Amoonguss can use Spore to disable the majority of the metagame and enable offensive partners in the process. It can also use Pollen Puff to keep its partners healthy as well as pressure Ogerpon-W with super effective chip damage

  • Amoonguss can utilize Sitrus Berry for burst healing and to survive the 2HKO from Choice Specs Flutter Mane's Shadow Ball. It can also opt for Rocky Helmet to punish physical attackers, especially Urshifu-R.

  • The HP EVS optimize Sitrus Berry recovery, and in conjunction with the Defense and Special Defense EVs, it survives the OHKO from Adamant Chien-Pao Ice Spinner and the 2HKO from Gholdengo's Shadow Ball, respectively.

  • Amoonguss makes use of Tera Water, as it synergizes with its original typing while keeping a resistance to Water. This enables it to take on Entei, Chien-Pao, and Incineroar while keeping its role as a consistent Urshifu-R answer. This is great for Amoonguss as many of these Pokemon like to partner together. Tera Fairy can be used instead to resist Urshifu-S's STAB moves and not be vulnerable to Ogerpon-W after Terastallizing.

Hydreigon.comments:
Teambuilding

  • Hydreigon is fast and offensive, so it works best on offensive teams. It appreciates having physical attackers next to it that can break down the special walls that Hydreigon struggles to break through, like Tyranitar and Sylveon. Hydreigon also enjoys having Tailwind and redirection support; Tailwind lets Hydreigon outspeed key threats like Dragapult, and redirection moves keep away threats like a Moonblast from Primarina. Choice Specs sets work even better with hyper-offensive playstyles due to the immense damage it can output.

  • Hydreigon appreciates Clefable, as it can support Hydreigon with Follow Me, absorbing dangerous Fairy-, Fighting-, and Dragon-type attacks like Moonblast, Outrage, and Close Combat. Hydreigon works well with powerful Ground-type attackers such as Garchomp and Ursaluna that can hit the Pokemon that Hydreigon cannot such as Archaludon with Earthquake, which Hydreigon is unaffected by. It also enjoys the presence of Gholdengo, which can switch in against status moves or Fake Out and threaten Fairy-types. Tailwind support from Talonflame or Whimsicott is also favored by Hydreigon for boosting Speed.

  • Hydreigon's main weakness is its inability to outspeed faster Dragon-types without Tailwind and its dangerous 4x weakness to Fairy. It also has a hard time hitting special walls like Tyranitar and Primarina. To mitigate this, it's important to have strong physical attackers on the team like Garchomp and Annihilape that can quickly empty the opposing team of special walls; to deal with faster Dragon-types, a Tailwind setter like Murkrow is necessary, and a Steel-type like Gholdengo will quickly rid the opposing team of Fairy-types.

Strategy Comments

  • Hydreigon fulfills its main role on teams as a damage dealer through its great stats and typing. It absolutely shines the most during the early-game, when it can spread heavy damage, then switch out and clean up other pieces late-game.

  • Hydreigon is best used when the opposing team no longer has any healthy special walls so that it can use its respectable Special Attack to pick off everything else.

  • Hydreigon has its biggest problems against PokÃ©mon that hard check and threaten it, such as Primarina and Archaludon. It's best to position your team to where these walls are either gone or heavily damaged before sending Hydreigon out to deal with them. Redirection from Clefable is also very appreciated to allow Hydreigon to spread damage uncontested.

Glass Cannon.description:
• Hydreigon uses its high Special Attack stat and good Speed stat to make it one of the faster and stronger threats in the current metagame. With its good offensive typing, Hydreigon ends up being a large threat to much of the metagame, such as Gholdengo and Garchomp.

  • Heat Wave provides Hydreigon with coverage against Kingambit, Rillaboom, and Tera Steel Gholdengo. Snarl gives Hydreigon a STAB option that lowers damage from foes like Archaludon.

  • Life Orb allows Hydreigon to use Protect and switch moves, whereas Choice Specs makes way for more damage but is less flexible. For instance, Choice Specs guarantees an OHKO on Ursaluna-B with a Draco Meteor, but Life Orb only guarantees a 2HKO.

  • Tera Poison and Tera Fire pair extremely well with Hydreigon due to both of them flipping some of Hydreigon's weaknesses into resistances. Tera Fire synergizes well with Heat Wave, providing a damage boost and letting Hydreigon resist Make It Rain's from Gholdengo; meanwhile, Tera Poison completely walls out Sneasler. Both options benefit from Levitate, negating the Ground weakness and making the Ursaluna formes and Garchomp less threatening.

Volcarona.comments:
Teambuilding

  • Setup Volcarona fits well on balance teams, as it requires utility and defensive support to enable it to sweep.
  • Rillaboom is an excellent teammate, as it uses Fake Out to give Volcarona room to set up and sets up Grassy Terrain that augments Volcarona's passive recovery and powers up Giga Drain. Redirectors like Clefable draw attacks away from Volcarona, letting it set up more easily. Intimidate users like Incineroar supplement Volcarona's ability to enhance its special bulk by reducing the damage of physical attackers.
  • Kingambit is a common teammate on the balance teams that Volcarona fits on. Assault Vest variants threaten foes like Incineroar, Tyranitar, and Dragapult that Volcarona struggles against. Another common choice on balance teams is Sneasler, which can threaten Rock-types and Incineroar that stuff Volcarona, and it can use Fake Out to give Volcarona room to set up or Coaching to bolster Volcarona's physical bulk.
  • If Volcarona has not Terastallized into a Fairy-type, it struggles with Dragon-types like Dragonite, so Fairy- and Dragon-types like Clefable and Dragapult can help it with that. Volcarona, before Terastallizing into a Grass- or Dragon-type, hates Water- and Rock-types like Basculegion-M and Tyranitar, so Grass-types like Rillaboom give it leeway against them. Additionally, Volcarona's coverage does not extend to Fire-types like Incineroar; Water-types like Primarina threaten them. Primarina also checks Dragon-types, making it a uniquely good teammate.

Strategy Comments

  • As a setup sweeper, Volcarona wants Fake Out support and redirection to give it breathing room to set up. The earlier in the game Volcarona can get set up, the more difficult it will be to remove it from the field, as a boosted Volcarona will be able to take multiple special attacks. Intimidate cycling assists in this, as it reinforces Volcarona's physical bulk to complement Quiver Dance, which boosts its special bulk.
  • Volcarona is actually one of the greatest adversaries of rain teams, as with redirection support from Electabuzz and Terastallization, it can boost to a level where it takes the special attacks of the rain attackers with ease. From there, its boosted attacks will rip apart these rain attackers and completely deny them the ability to revenge kill it. In these matchups, it's better to avoid using too many attacks on Archaludon, as its Stamina-boosted Body Press will eventually become too strong for Volcarona to handle. Early in the game, Pelipper threatens Volcarona with both of its STAB moves, so redirection will prevent Volcarona from being KOed by Pelipper before it can get set up. Additionally, Swift Swim Basculegion-M is a threat before Volcarona has set up, easily outspeeding and overwhelming it with rain-boosted Water-type attacks.
  • Volcarona lacks coverage to threaten Dragon-types unless it has Terastallized into a Fairy-type, so the likes of Dragapult and Dragonite can take it on effectively. This extends to Tera Dragon Pokemon like Gholdengo, which gain the ability to resist its Fire-type STAB moves. Fairy- and fast Dragon-types like Clefable and Scale Shot Dragonite threaten these Dragon-types. Similarly, Fire-types like Incineroar and Tera Fire users like Rillaboom can deal with both of its attacks, and they are also immune to burns from Heat Wave and Flame Body; Water-types like Primarina can deal with these Pokemon.
